recommended_movies: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night (2014)

simulated_ratings.title: Alien (1979)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Unnerving and beautifully paced, its eerie isolation and slow-burn dread hit my sweet spot.

simulated_ratings.title: The Thing (1982)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Paranoia and creature terror executed with razor-sharp precision kept me on edge.

simulated_ratings.title: The Shining (1980)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Mesmerizing, icy atmosphere and methodical escalation that lingers long after.

simulated_ratings.title: The Descent (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Claustrophobic, feral tension and relentless darkness really worked for me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Orphanage (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A tender, somber ghost story whose emotional core amplifies the chills.

simulated_ratings.title: Pan's Labyrinth (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A haunting dark fable where imaginative fantasy deepens the real-world horror.

simulated_ratings.title: The Witch (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Glossy action-fantasy vibes smother the kind of creeping dread I look for.

simulated_ratings.title: Hereditary (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Oppressive, slow-burn family horror that crawled under my skin.

simulated_ratings.title: Evil Dead II (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Inventive and wild, though the slapstick dilutes the fear slightly for me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Others (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Candlelit atmosphere and careful reveals make for a poised, satisfying haunt.

simulated_ratings.title: The Babadook (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Strong metaphor-driven dread, a bit on-the-nose yet gripping.

simulated_ratings.title: Train to Busan (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Propulsive, heartfelt survival horror with tension to spare.

simulated_ratings.title: The Wailing (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slow, moody folk terror that rewards patience with deep unease.

simulated_ratings.title: Noroi: The Curse (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A creeping, documentary-style nightmare that builds a convincing myth.

simulated_ratings.title: The Devil's Backbone (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Elegiac and chilling, its wartime sorrow enriches the supernatural.

simulated_ratings.title: Only Lovers Left Alive (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Languid and moody, I enjoyed the vibe more than the momentum.

simulated_ratings.title: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Coolly hypnotic and stylish, its nocturnal mood really lands.

simulated_ratings.title: Annihilation (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Introspective sci-fi horror with striking imagery and a lingering eeriness.

simulated_ratings.title: Arrival (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Elegant, thoughtful sci-fi that resonates emotionally and intellectually.

simulated_ratings.title: Sunshine (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Strong atmosphere and ideas, even if the final stretch wobbles.

simulated_ratings.title: Moon (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quiet, human sci-fi that sneaks up on you emotionally.

simulated_ratings.title: Stalker (1979)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A transfixing, contemplative journey that rewards patience and reflection.

simulated_ratings.title: Solaris (1972)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Meditative and cerebral—occasionally distant but deeply absorbing.

simulated_ratings.title: Under the Skin (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sensual and opaque

simulated_ratings.title: Zodiac (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Meticulous and absorbing, valuing mood and obsession over cheap thrills.

simulated_ratings.title: Se7en (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Relentless and grim, with expertly sustained dread.

simulated_ratings.title: The Silence of the Lambs (1991)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Taut and unnerving, its psychological chill still cuts deep.

simulated_ratings.title: The Haunting (1963)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A hushed, suggestive chill—sound and shadow doing the heavy lifting I love.

simulated_ratings.title: The Innocents (1961)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Candlelit dread and ambiguity that prickles long after.

simulated_ratings.title: Don't Look Now (1973)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grief-soaked unease with images that burrow under the skin.

simulated_ratings.title: The Changeling (1980)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Elegant, mournful haunting with steady, rewarding chills.

simulated_ratings.title: It Follows (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: This prison-break yarn doesn’t tap the creeping dread I seek, leaving me cold.

simulated_ratings.title: Cure (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Transfixing, disorienting paranoia that tightens like a noose.

simulated_ratings.title: Pulse (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleak, lonely techno-haunt that seeps in like a fog.

simulated_ratings.title: A Tale of Two Sisters (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lush, melancholic nightmare with patient, suffocating tension.

simulated_ratings.title: The Invitation (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Skillful grappling perhaps, but zero of the atmospheric menace I crave.

simulated_ratings.title: The Autopsy of Jane Doe (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Claustrophobic and occult, with dread mounting in every incision.

simulated_ratings.title: Under the Shadow (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: War-torn domestic terror where emotion deepens the haunt.

simulated_ratings.title: The Lighthouse (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Salt-soaked madness and isolation—mesmeric, abrasive, and my kind of slow descent.

simulated_ratings.title: The Empty Man (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A roomy, occult mood-piece whose ominous sprawl mostly worked on me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Fog (1980)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Coastal ghost-story vibes and old-school atmosphere that gently creep.

simulated_ratings.title: Videodrome (1983)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Body-horror ideas and media paranoia delivered with queasy allure.

simulated_ratings.title: Possession (1981)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Feral, unhinged psychosis that feels like being trapped in a fever.

simulated_ratings.title: Jacob's Ladder (1990)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sorrowful, paranoid unraveling that gnaws steadily.

simulated_ratings.title: Invasion of the Body Snatchers (1978)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Urban paranoia rendered with cool, inexorable dread.

simulated_ratings.title: The Andromeda Strain (1971)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clinical, procedural sci-fi suspense that rewards patience.

simulated_ratings.title: Coherence (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Low-key, brain-twisty dinner-party dread right in my wheelhouse.

simulated_ratings.title: The Vast of Night (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Whispery, midnight-radio mood that quietly enthralls.

simulated_ratings.title: Children of Men (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Visceral, humane sci-fi that grips the heart and the nerves.

simulated_ratings.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Somber, hypnotic future-noir that invites immersion and reflection.

simulated_ratings.title: Predator (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Muscular creature suspense that thrills more than it unnerves.

simulated_ratings.title: An American Werewolf in London (1981)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sharp transformation terror, with the humor softening the sting.

simulated_ratings.title: The House of the Devil (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Patient, retro dread that blossoms into a deliciously satanic snap.

simulated_ratings.title: Kill List (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleak, disorienting descent from crime grime into occult dread that left a chill.

simulated_ratings.title: The Vanishing (1988)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A merciless, methodical nightmare whose calm inevitability gnawed at me.

simulated_ratings.title: Picnic at Hanging Rock (1975)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sun-dazed mystery and whispering absence that haunt more than they explain.

simulated_ratings.title: The Night of the Hunter (1955)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Expressionist fairy-tale terror with images that lodge under the skin.

simulated_ratings.title: The Wicker Man (1973)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sunny folk horror whose ritualistic unease tightens beautifully to a sting.

simulated_ratings.title: Session 9 (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Crumbly walls and frayed minds weave a damp, convincing dread.

simulated_ratings.title: Prince of Darkness (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Apocalyptic pulp wrapped in chilly Carpenter mood that mostly works.

simulated_ratings.title: Dark Water (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Mournful urban haunt where slow leakage becomes suffocating grief.

simulated_ratings.title: Onibaba (1964)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Swampy lust and war-scarred hunger curdle into primal, mask-borne terror.

simulated_ratings.title: Kuroneko (1968)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moonlit, elegiac vengeance that drifts like smoke and cuts like claws.

simulated_ratings.title: Hour of the Wolf (1968)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Anxious, nocturnal hallucination where guilt and monsters blur exquisitely.

simulated_ratings.title: The Reflecting Skin (1990)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Pastoral Americana curdled into a cruel dream that unsettled more than it satisfied.

simulated_ratings.title: Silent Running (1972)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Melancholy eco-sci‑fi with tender loneliness, a touch earnest but affecting.

simulated_ratings.title: Dark City (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Shadowy, reality-warping noir that scratches my itch for moody sci-fi.

simulated_ratings.title: The Parallax View (1974)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cool, creeping conspiracy paranoia that closes like a trap.

simulated_ratings.title: The Conversation (1974)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Hushed, meticulous surveillance anxiety that burrowed straight into me.

simulated_ratings.title: Aguirre, the Wrath of God (1972)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Hypnotic river-madness—grandeur and doom drifting in lockstep.

simulated_ratings.title: Come and See (1985)
simulated_ratings.feeling: War as waking nightmare—devastating, immersive, and hard to shake.

simulated_ratings.title: Memories of Murder (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleakly funny, despairing procedural whose damp gloom lingers.

simulated_ratings.title: Eraserhead (1977)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Industrial fever-dream I admire more than I connect with.

simulated_ratings.title: Mulholland Drive (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Seductive, fractured noir whose dream logic I’m happy to drown in.

simulated_ratings.title: Thirst (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sensual, perverse vampirism—compelling, if a bit overheated for my taste.

simulated_ratings.title: The Brood (1979)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Psychosomatic fury with sticky ideas that outpace its chill.

simulated_ratings.title: Dead Ringers (1988)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clinical, intimate descent that aches as it horrifies.

simulated_ratings.title: Possessor (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Icy, identity-splitting sci‑fi horror that hums with controlled menace.

simulated_ratings.title: The Night House (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Zany, retro-tinged antics blunt the dread I’m chasing.

simulated_ratings.title: A Dark Song (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Ritualistic rigor and grief-borne resolve conjure a potent, patient chill.

simulated_ratings.title: Relic (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grief-soaked domestic haunt where slow decay and dementia bloom into chilling, resonant dread.

simulated_ratings.title: Kwaidan (1965)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Elegant, candlelit folk phantoms unfurl with hypnotic patience that I happily sink into.

simulated_ratings.title: The Exorcist III (1990)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody, procedural evil with patient chills and a few bone-deep jolts that linger.

simulated_ratings.title: Ringu (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Ancient curse meets analogue unease in a slow, suffocating spiral that seeped under my skin.

simulated_ratings.title: The Ninth Configuration (1980)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Philosophical melancholy and gallows humor intrigue more than they chill, but the mood sticks.

simulated_ratings.title: The Little Stranger (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Austere, decaying-house dread that whispers effectively, if a bit too cool to fully haunt.

simulated_ratings.title: Personal Shopper (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Airless grief and modern hauntings intertwine into a cool, humming trance I vibed with.

simulated_ratings.title: The Borderlands (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Forest-bound mystery with supernatural hints

simulated_ratings.title: The Endless (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cosmic-cult melancholy and looping unease create a gently mind-bending, ominous lull.

simulated_ratings.title: Apostle (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grimy folk terror and cult cruelty

simulated_ratings.title: The Ritual (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Guilt-ridden woodland trek with a fine creaturely dread and sturdy, creeping atmosphere.

simulated_ratings.title: The Blair Witch Project (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Leaf-littered panic and offscreen terror coalesce into pure, primitive unease.

simulated_ratings.title: The Texas Chain Saw Massacre (1974)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Raw, sun-baked nightmare energy that grinds the nerves more than it shocks.

simulated_ratings.title: Vampyr (1932)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Fog-draped, dream-logic specters weave a fragile, entrancing chill.

simulated_ratings.title: Nosferatu the Vampyre (1979)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sorrowful, miasmic vampirism that drifts with haunting, mournful weight.

simulated_ratings.title: Peeping Tom (1960)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clinical, voyeuristic dread that slides under the skin with unnerving intimacy.

simulated_ratings.title: The Tenant (1976)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Hermetic paranoia and identity slippage tightening into a queasy, claustrophobic spell.

simulated_ratings.title: Manhunter (1986)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cool, neon-tinged procedural menace—methodical, absorbing, and quietly chilling.

simulated_ratings.title: The Pledge (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A bleak, methodical pursuit whose calm despair left a slow ache.

simulated_ratings.title: Blow Out (1981)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Velvety paranoia and fatal inevitability woven into a gripping, night-swept conspiracy trance.

simulated_ratings.title: Klute (1971)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Urban hush and character anxiety create a subtle, steady tingle of dread.

simulated_ratings.title: All the President's Men (1976)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Procedural rigor and mounting hush make conspiracy feel inexorable and enthralling.

simulated_ratings.title: Seconds (1966)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Surgical identity horror and mid-century paranoia wrapped in stark, unsettling elegance.

simulated_ratings.title: The Manchurian Candidate (1962)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cold-war hypnosis and creeping fatalism delivered with cool, tightening dread.

simulated_ratings.title: Upstream Color (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lyrical, symbiotic sci‑fi whose dreamy dislocation casts a lingering spell.

simulated_ratings.title: Timecrimes (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever, tightening loops spiral into low-key, nerve-prickling inevitability.
